title: No Corrections: July 13, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 13, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 13, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Amitabh Bachchan, Russia Protests, Poland Election: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cheryl Lock
title: How to Help Kids Cope With Moving
description: A move may mean a welcome change of scenery for you, but to young children it can present an insecure world.
content: When my husband and I decided to buy a new house at the end of last year, we spent very little time considering what the move would mean to our two daughters, who were 3 and 22 months at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Goldblatt
title: How to Shoot a Sex Scene in a Pandemic: Cue the Mannequins
description: TV shows like “The Bold and the Beautiful,” “Riverdale” and “The L Word: Generation Q” are trying to figure out how to responsibly film physical intimacy in the time of coronavirus.
content: Of all the weird ways that Covid-19 has affected life in this country, one of the most bizarre is taking place on a soundstage in Los Angeles. That’s where actors on the CBS soap opera “The Bold and the Beautiful” have been shooting intimate scenes with mannequins.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Big Friendship,’ by Aminatou Sow: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Big Friendship,” by Aminatou Sow
content: We’re now a full decade into our friendship. We’ve lived apart for more than twice as long as we lived in the same city. We still see a lot of each other and talk almost daily, although the years of watching TV on the couch or lingering at happy hour every week feel very far away. The truth is that it’s harder for us to fit into each other’s lives than it once was—and we work together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: McEnany Plays Down Tensions Between White House and Fauci
description: White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany disputed reports that the Trump administration was sending “opposition research” against Dr. Anthony S. Fauci to news organizations.
content: White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany disputed reports that the Trump administration was sending “opposition research” against Dr. Anthony S. Fauci to news organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica St. Clair and Dan O'Brien
title: How a Couple Got Each Other Through Cancer
description: What happens when the parents of a young daughter have consecutive bouts of cancer? They close ranks — and reach out.
content: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Reissue of John Cage’s Mushroom Book
description: The composer was also a forager who sold his finds to the Four Seasons. Now, you can buy a new edition of his 1972 book.
content: The composer John Cage was also a passionate mycologist. He even sold the fungal fruits of his foraging to the Four Seasons Restaurant in Manhattan. In 1972, he wrote a limited-edition book about mushrooms with Alexander H. Smith and Lois Long. Now the “Mushroom Book,” a reproduction with lithographic illustrations, anecdotes, poetry and even authors’ scribblings, has been reissued in a boxed set with “A Mycological Foray by Cage and others. The collectors edition, limited to 500 copies, also includes a box of postcards with Cage’s mushroom recipes; the regular edition of 4,500 omits the recipe box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: New Seasoned Fonio Pilafs From Pierre Thiam
description: The chef, an ambassador for the West African grain, now sells preseasoned instant packs of gluten-free fonio.
content: Pierre Thiam, a native of Senegal, has become the American ambassador for fonio, the versatile West African grain. He’s written a book about it. Now in addition to selling plain fonio, which cooks up like fine couscous, his company, Yolélé, has introduced tasty, efficient fonio pilafs. They are preseasoned with several flavor profiles: Yassa, with onion, lime and chile; Jollof, with tomato and bell pepper; Afro-Funk, with herbs and fermented locust bean; Dakar Curry, with currants; and Greens, with moringa and spinach. Each package, with the addition of some oil and water, makes enough fine-textured light and fluffy grain for four as a main or six as a side dish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Judy Dyble, Singer in Fairport Convention and Beyond, Dies at 71
description: Her crystalline soprano drew on folk tradition, but she also embraced psychedelia and progressive rock.
content: Judy Dyble, a singer and songwriter who was in the first recorded lineup of the British folk-rock institution Fairport Convention before going on to an extensive, though interrupted, recording career, died on Sunday in Oxfordshire, England. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Was Trump Doing a Favor for Roger Stone, or Himself?
description: Readers discuss the commutation of Mr. Stone’s jail sentence in terms of politics and the law.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: ‘We’re Not an Island’: Rural Outbreaks Challenge Oregon’s Virus Success
description: Oregon was sandwiched between two states that had big coronavirus outbreaks but managed to keep its numbers low. Until it couldn’t.
content: HERMISTON, Ore. — Jose Garcia reached into the bed of his pickup truck and gingerly withdrew a sealed plastic bag. Inside was a homemade mask Mr. Garcia had been given by a worker in one of the sprawling agricultural fields that surround his home in northeastern Oregon. The mask was made of a single, neatly folded paper towel with a rubber band stapled to each end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Frakt
title: What’s Missing in the Effort to Stop Maternal Deaths
description: The U.S. could prevent two-thirds of deaths during or within a year of pregnancy, research suggests.
content: According to the best data available, as summarized in a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the United States could prevent two-thirds of maternal deaths during or within a year of pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Pop Smoke and ‘Hamilton’ Shake Up the Billboard Chart
description: The posthumous debut album by the Brooklyn rapper landed at No. 1, becoming one of the biggest releases of a slow summer in music.
content: The posthumous debut album by the Brooklyn rapper Pop Smoke, who was shot and killed in February, debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week, arriving as one of the biggest releases of a slow summer in the music business, one of countless industries greatly affected by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Driver Purposely Drove Bus Into China Reservoir, Killing 21, Police Say
description: The 52-year-old driver, who was also killed, was aggrieved about the demolition of his home because of a redevelopment scheme, officials said.
content: A bus crash in southwest China last week that killed 21 people and injured 15 others was caused by the driver, who deliberately steered into a reservoir because he was angry at the demolition of his home, the police have said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Fracking Firms Fail, Rewarding Executives and Raising Climate Fears
description: Oil and gas companies are hurtling toward bankruptcy, raising fears that wells will be left leaking planet-warming pollutants, with cleanup costs left to taxpayers.
content: The day the debt-ridden Texas oil producer MDC Energy filed for bankruptcy eight months ago, a tank at one of its wells was furiously leaking methane, a potent greenhouse gas, into the atmosphere. As of last week, dangerous, invisible gases were still spewing into the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Florida Sheriff’s Deputy Is Fired After Pointing Gun at Unarmed Man
description: Sergeant Janak Amin, a 21-year veteran of the Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office, has been charged with aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, the sheriff said.
content: A sergeant with the Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office in Tampa, Fla., has been fired and charged with assault after he pointed a gun at an unarmed man for refusing to give his name, the sheriff said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Michael Schwirtz
title: How Russia Built a Channel to the Taliban, Once an Enemy
description: The recent assessment that Russia paid bounties to the insurgents to attack U.S. troops stunned many, but officials said the Kremlin’s outreach began almost a decade ago.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — During one of the most violent stretches of fighting in northern Afghanistan, as the Taliban scored victories that had eluded them since the beginning of the conflict, the top American commander went public with a suspicion that had nagged for years: Russia was aiding the insurgents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Medicine Cabinets
description: Is your bathroom a mess? Here are five ideas for cleaning it up.
content: If your bathroom looks more like a cluttered pharmacy than a peaceful retreat, a generously sized medicine cabinet could help clean things up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: NBC Starts Streaming With a TV-Style Platform, Peacock
description: The service will challenge Netflix with a digital version of channel-surfing and lots of what one executive calls “comfort-food TV.”
content: NBCUniversal’s streaming platform, Peacock, looks a whole lot like broadcast TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Michael Gold
title: 1-Year-Old Is Shot and Killed at Brooklyn Cookout
description: The child’s death capped another weekend of gun violence in New York City, where shootings in June and July have risen sharply.
content: The cookout in Brooklyn on Sunday night was like many other outdoor parties in New York City during the pandemic. People gathered around a smoldering grill near a park late on a warm summer evening. The group included a 1-year-old boy in a stroller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: He Beat Trump and Weinstein. Why Is This D.A.’s Standing Still Shaky?
description: The Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., has two big recent victories, but still has not said whether he is seeking re-election.
content: He just won a landmark victory in the Supreme Court over President Trump that paved the way for prosecutors to obtain the president’s tax returns. In February, he won a conviction against Harvey Weinstein in perhaps the biggest criminal case to arise from the #MeToo movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Nicole Hong
title: Ghislaine Maxwell Tried to Hide When F.B.I. Knocked, Prosecutors Say
description: On the day of her arrest, Ms. Maxwell, a longtime companion of Jeffrey Epstein, refused to answer the door and fled to another room, according to a new court filing.
content: When F.B.I. agents went to arrest Ghislaine Maxwell on the morning of July 2 on a remote property in New Hampshire, they broke through her locked gate, approached the front door and announced themselves, telling her to open the door, federal prosecutors said in newly filed court papers on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester City Won. Now Brace for the Losses.
description: City’s victory will be welcomed by rivals with deep pockets. But the demise of cost-control rules risks destabilizing teams and a sport already shaken by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: MANCHESTER, England — Manchester City has its answer: the answer it wanted, the answer it was adamant, right from the start, was the only one possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: A Health Worker Raised Alarms About the Coronavirus. Then He Lost His Job.
description: A lawsuit by a nursing home employee in Italy will test whether health care professionals are paying a price for pointing out dangerous conditions at medical facilities.
content: MILAN — In February, he said the directors of the nursing home where he worked kept him from wearing a mask, fearing it would scare patients and their families. In March, he became infected and spoke out about the coronavirus spreading through the home. In May, he was fired amid claims that he had “damaged the company’s image.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: In Astounding Test, Scientists Revive Damaged Lungs for Transplant
description: Injured and unusable lungs were restored with respirators and pig blood. The procedure one day may increase the supply of organs for transplant.
content: The six lungs were taken from brain-dead patients and offered to transplant surgeons. But at major medical centers, one surgeon after another refused the organs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Bahrain to Execute 2 Shiite Protesters After Years of Desperate Appeals
description: The men were convicted of a bombing that killed a police officer in 2014. They say they were tortured into making a false confession during Bahrain’s escalating crackdown on critics.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two Bahraini men who say they were tortured into making false confessions were sentenced to death for the fifth time on Monday in what international rights groups called another stain on Bahrain’s record of imprisoning, torturing and executing government critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Marc Santora
title: After Tight Race for Polish President, Andrzej Duda Wins 2nd Term
description: The close fight revealed deep divisions, but Mr. Duda’s victory cleared the path for Poland’s government to continue with a nationalist agenda that critics fear is undermining democratic institutions.
content: WARSAW — President Andrzej Duda of Poland was narrowly elected to a second term after the votes were counted on Monday following the country’s closest presidential election since the end of communist rule in 1989, clearing a potential obstacle for the conservative nationalist government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Najim Rahim
title: Taliban Stage a Major Attack, as Violence Intensifies in Northern Afghanistan
description: Insurgents bombed the entrance of an Afghan intelligence complex in a provincial capital, then stormed the offices in a sustained gun battle, killing at least 11.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban waged a sustained assault against an Afghan intelligence complex in the city of Aybak on Monday, killing at least 11 people and wounding more than 60 others, part of a bloody wave of violence across the country’s north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan Will Scrap Alcohol and Apostasy Laws, and End Flogging
description: The moves are part of efforts to broaden personal freedoms during a delicate democratic transition.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudan will allow non-Muslims to consume alcohol, scrap its apostasy law and abolish the use of public flogging as a punishment as its transitional government eases decades of strict Islamist policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Noah Weiland
title: Fauci Back at the White House, a Day After Trump Aides Tried to Undermine Him
description: The visit underscored a reality for both the president and his most prominent coronavirus adviser: They are stuck with each other.
content: WASHINGTON — A day after President Trump’s press office tried to undermine the reputation of the nation’s top infectious disease expert with an anonymously attributed list of what it said were his misjudgments in the early days of the coronavirus, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci returned to the White House on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: ‘A Slap in the Face’: N.Y. Town Rejects Black Lives Matter Painting
description: The debate over whether to allow the street art has exacerbated racial tensions in Catskill, where just over a fifth of the population is Black.
content: CATSKILL, N.Y. — The street painting would stretch about three blocks, from Village Pizza II to the stoplight at the southern end of Main Street, spelling out “Black Lives Matter” on the pavement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Cheung
title: Life in Hong Kong Has Always Been Impossible
description: “Take care tonight/ Things might not look like this tomorrow.”
content: Last year, in July, a month after the protests over an extradition bill began in Hong Kong, I renewed the lease on my flat. For the first time since I turned 18, I would be living in the same apartment for more than two years. It felt like an accomplishment, like I was a real adult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Akerman
title: Did Mueller Ever Stand a Chance Against Trump and Roger Stone?
description: I was a Watergate prosecutor. I know why he didn’t.
content: In 1973, I served as an assistant special prosecutor for the Watergate Special Prosecution Force, which investigated the connection between the White House and the break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters, the subsequent cover-up and other crimes connected with the White House under Richard Nixon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: America Drank Away Its Children’s Future
description: As the school year looms, the pandemic is still raging.
content: A brief history of the past four months in America:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Sebelius
title: Attention All Women: Trump Is Coming for Your Health Care
description: Even with a pandemic raging, the president wants the Supreme Court to strike down the Affordable Care Act.
content: In the middle of a catastrophic public health crisis, the Trump administration has asked the Supreme Court to overturn the entire Affordable Care Act. This is dangerous for many reasons — but for women, it’s devastating. They would be stripped of the protections they have had in the decade since passage of the law, known as Obamacare.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump in a Mask, at Last!
description: A reader is stunned that it’s “world news” when the president finally yields to pleas that he wear a mask.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Rivas
title: I’m an Actor of Color. My Curls Aren’t Wanted.
description: I know if I want to land more roles, I need to look white.
content: Actors of color trying to make it in Hollywood face a paradox: To succeed, you need to stand out from the crowd while assimilating as much as possible. Be yourself while fitting in. And if you aspire to be like one of those leading men you grew up watching on TV, well, you better look the part. Step 1: Calm those curls. In the video above, Dominican-American actor Christopher Rivas reflects from the barber’s chair on the hundreds of crew cuts he’s gotten over the course of his career in hopes of appeasing casting directors who have a certain unwavering vision of how a star actor looks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Kenna
title: Behold Vermont, From Above
description: These aerial images, stunning in their abstraction, evoke a powerful sense of transcendence and tranquility.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Caleb Kenna shares a collection of drone photographs from Vermont.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Michael Lewis, Who Forged a New Life After Prison, Dies at 65
description: Mr. Lewis counseled newly released inmates on how to adjust to life on the outside, using a simple orange bag to make his point. He died from the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Women’s Rights Activists Describe Seoul Mayor’s Alleged Abuse
description: A women’s rights activist group in Seoul called for an investigation into abuse allegations against Mayor Park Won-soon, who committed suicide last week.
content: A women’s rights activist group in Seoul called for an investigation into abuse allegations against Mayor Park Won-soon, who committed suicide last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Soap With a Brisket Back Story
description: Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque is repurposing fat from its meat into rustic bars of soap.
content: Making soap basically requires two ingredients: fat and lye. Micha Magid, an owner of Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque, with a number of stores in New York and New Jersey, had a lot of fat in his kitchen. “We would trim the whole briskets before smoking them and were throwing away tons and tons of fat,” he said. “I was looking for a way to repurpose it.” He started making soap with the fat, plus lye, peppermint oil and organic charcoal. “It seemed to be a really good idea now that everyone has to wash their hands all the time,” he said. The blocks of charcoal gray soap are effective, and are sold in its stores and on the company’s website. Mighty Quinn’s is donating 25 percent of sales to No Kid Hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: She Found Her Voice in a W.N.B.A. Locker Room, Then Used It in Sweden
description: Amanda Zahui B. wanted to rush back to the U.S. after George Floyd’s death. But she realized there was work to be done back home.
content: Four years ago, the Liberty became one of the first professional sports franchises to make a unified on-court statement against police brutality and racial injustice. Even before Colin Kaepernick drew widespread attention for kneeling during the N.F.L. preseason later that summer, the Liberty took the court for a game wearing black shirts that said #BlackLivesMatter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Daughter’s Obituary Blames Politicians for Arizona Man’s Virus Death
description: Kristin Urquiza, writing about her father’s death, pointed the finger at how state and federal leaders have handled the coronavirus pandemic.
content: When Kristin Urquiza’s father died last month in Arizona, she wrote an obituary that offered not one but two causes of death: the coronavirus, and ineptitude on the part of government officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Hughes
title: Nannies Wanted: Covid-19 Antibodies Preferred
description: During the pandemic, caregivers are being asked to do more than ever, from cleaning and cooking to teaching algebra.
content: The Facebook post started like lots of others in the Brooklyn parents’ group: “Looking for some part time child care, a few mornings a week, for a 3-year-old.” Then, “Ideally, we’re looking for someone who has lots and lots of energy, and has already had Covid-19.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: How I Came Out About My Disability
description: Three writers share how they revealed their disability, to a family member, to a love interest on a dating app and to oneself.
content: This article is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for people with disabilities. Share your stories or email us at ada@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Ted Cruz Was Seen on a Flight Without a Mask. His Office Says He Followed Airline Policy.
description: The senator’s office says he wears a mask when traveling and temporarily takes it off to eat or drink.
content: American Airlines said on Monday that it had reached out to Senator Ted Cruz after a widely shared photograph showed him not wearing a mask on one of its flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish Colonial Revival house in Ojai, a 1901 Victorian in San Francisco and a Southwestern-style home in Santa Monica.
content: This house was designed by George Washington Smith, a Santa Barbara architect who helped popularize the Spanish Colonial Revival style in the early 20th century. Mr. Smith, a bond trader-turned-painter who took up architecture after designing his own farmhouse in Montecito, was commissioned to build this house and several others in Ojai by Edward Drummond Libbey, a glass manufacturer who owned a number of buildings in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Oliver Stone Thinks Hollywood Has Gone Crazy
description: “The Academy changes its mind every five, 10, two months about what it’s trying to keep up with. … I’ve never seen it quite mad like this.”
content: “The Academy changes its mind every five, 10, two months about what it’s trying to keep up with. … I’ve never seen it quite mad like this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Celebrate Paul Prudhomme’s birthday with blackened fish and dirty rice, or make a coconut pecan cake.
content: Good morning. It is the chef Paul Prudhomme’s birthday, and he’d have been 80 had he survived the illness that led to his death in 2015. Prudhomme, as William Grimes put it in his obituary for The Times, “put the cooking of Louisiana — especially the Cajun gumbos, jambalayas and dirty rice he grew up with — on the American culinary map.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Tae McDermott
title: Are State Parks and Campgrounds Open in California?
description: You can visit most of California’s state and national parks, but here’s what to know before you go.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Turning Point for Hong Kong
description: New legislation has chilled Hong Kong’s pro-democracy movement — and potentially altered the city forever.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Los Angeles Apparel Factory Shut Down After More Than 300 Coronavirus Cases
description: The company’s chief executive, Dov Charney, had staged a professional comeback by making masks. Four workers have died from the virus.
content: In mid-March, as the coronavirus raged across New York, Washington State, California and New Jersey, and the crisis in personal protection equipment shortages grew, Dov Charney of Los Angeles Apparel was one of the first clothing retailers to step into the void.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Now That the Redskins Are Gone, Who’s Next?
description: Expect increased pressure on other teams to change their nicknames and logos, including the Braves, Indians and Chiefs.
content: Expect increased pressure on other teams to change their nicknames and logos, including the Braves, Indians and Chiefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Have You Moved Any Activities Outside?
description: We want to hear about innovative steps that companies, government agencies and other organizations have taken to hold activities outdoors.
content: Outdoors is safer than indoors. That’s one of the main arguments that public health experts have been making. If more activities move outdoors — school classes, work meetings, religious services, restaurant dining — the coronavirus is likely to spread less rapidly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Initial Roger Stone Fallout
description: “Unprecedented, historic corruption,” Romney calls a commutation: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: The Stone commutation leaves some Republicans cold, Trump dons a mask and Pelosi pushes for another round of relief. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Brave New World’ Arrives in the Future It Predicted
description: On Wednesday, Peacock premieres an adaptation of Aldous Huxley’s 1932 science fiction novel. The world the book anticipated — designer drugs, casual sex, near-instant gratification — is already here.
content: Ready for a thought experiment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Violin Vigils Honor the Memory of Elijah McClain
description: Mr. McClain, who played the violin, died while being detained by the police in Colorado last summer.
content: Ashanti Floyd couldn’t sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Remaining PGA Tour Events Will Not Host Fans
description: The organizers of four upcoming tournaments announced on Monday that they would hold those events without spectators.
content: The remainder of the PGA Tour schedule this season will be played without spectators after the organizers of four tournaments announced on Monday that they would close their events to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Jeff Sessions and Tommy Tuberville Close Out Alabama’s G.O.P. Senate Runoff
description: Mr. Sessions, the former attorney general and current Trump adversary, and Mr. Tuberville, a former Auburn University football coach, will face voters on Tuesday.
content: MOBILE, Ala. — Jeff Sessions, the Alabama Republican and former attorney general who is trying to reclaim his old Senate seat, on Monday declined to answer directly whether he would support his opponent, Tommy Tuberville, in the general election in the event that Mr. Sessions does not win Tuesday’s runoff race against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hong Kong Disneyland to Close Again, Days After Disney World Reopens
description: The park is the smallest in Disney’s portfolio and is shutting down again to comply with a government-mandated rollback of public activities because of the coronavirus.
content: Hong Kong Disneyland will close again on Wednesday to comply with a government-directed rollback of public activities in the region after an increase in coronavirus infections, the Walt Disney Company said on Monday. Disney called the closing of the theme park “temporary” and said its resort hotels at the Lantau Island complex would remain open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez, Rick Rojas, Shawn Hubler and Mike Baker
title: America’s Governors Get Tested for a Virus That Is Testing Them
description: The pandemic has put many governors of both parties under a spotlight for which none of their aides and consultants have a playbook.
content: HOUSTON — Governors have always been judged on their disaster responses, but the coronavirus wreaking havoc across the country these days does not recede like floodwaters and cannot be tamed by calling out the National Guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Bottleneck for U.S. Coronavirus Response: The Fax Machine
description: Before public health officials can manage the pandemic, they must deal with a broken data system that sends incomplete results in formats they can’t easily use.
content: Public health officials in Houston are struggling to keep up with one of the nation’s largest coronavirus outbreaks. They are desperate to trace cases and quarantine patients before they spread the virus to others. But first, they must negotiate with the office fax machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: White Supremacist Who Admitted Christchurch Killings Plans to Represent Himself
description: There is concern that the Australian who pleaded guilty to killing 51 worshipers at two mosques in New Zealand last year would use the occasion to spout his views.
content: An Australian white supremacist who pleaded guilty to killing 51 worshipers at two mosques in New Zealand last year plans to represent himself at a sentencing hearing in August, a court heard on Monday, raising concerns that he might use the proceedings to push his views and traumatize the survivors once again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Posner
title: What a Second Trump Term Would Look Like
description: He won’t overthrow the Constitution. But he might persuade Americans that democracy just does not work.
content: Back when Donald Trump was running for president in 2016, Republican leaders claimed to believe that, as president, Mr. Trump would respect the rule of law. “I still believe we have the institutions of government that would restrain someone who seeks to exceed their constitutional obligations,” Senator John McCain said. “We have a Congress. We have the Supreme Court. We’re not Romania.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Gillian R. Brassil
title: For Native American Activists, Washington Name Change Was ‘a Long Time Coming’
description: The Washington N.F.L. team has long been a target of protests but now that its owner has budged, activists are pushing for other teams to follow suit.
content: Activists have spent decades pressuring professional sports leagues, college programs and high schools to abandon Native American names and imagery for their teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Jeff Sessions and Tommy Tuberville Close Out Alabama’s G.O.P. Senate Runoff
description: Mr. Sessions, the former attorney general and current Trump adversary, and Mr. Tuberville, a former Auburn University football coach, will face voters on Tuesday.
content: MOBILE, Ala. — Jeff Sessions, the Alabama Republican and former attorney general who is trying to reclaim his old Senate seat, on Monday declined to answer directly whether he would support his opponent, Tommy Tuberville, in the general election in the event that Mr. Sessions does not win Tuesday’s runoff race against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Body of Naya Rivera Is Found at California Lake, Authorities Say
description: Ms. Rivera, 33, disappeared last week after going boating on Lake Piru with her young son.
content: Investigators on Monday were “confident” they had found the body of Naya Rivera, a star in the series “Glee,” almost a week after she was reported missing at a lake in California, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Fenwick
title: The Massacre That Destroyed Tulsa’s ‘Black Wall Street’
description: In 1921, the city of Tulsa erupted in a spasm of hate and fire that destroyed its prosperous Black district. A century later, excavators are uncovering a “crime scene.”
content: TULSA, Okla. — Incited by a salacious and largely fabricated news story about a young Black man assaulting a white girl, a lynch mob showed up at the Tulsa city jail, where he was being held. A group of African-Americans, many of them soldiers who had returned from fighting the First World War, rushed over to help guard the young man. Fighting broke out, then shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart
title: These Are the Deutsche Bank Executives Responsible for Serving Jeffrey Epstein
description: When New York regulators punished the bank for its work with Mr. Epstein, no individuals were named. The Times identified them.
content: Jeffrey Epstein, the sex criminal and financier, didn’t act alone. Now we know in vivid detail who some of his financial enablers were: executives and bankers at Deutsche Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: How May Google Fight an Antitrust Case? Look at This Little-Noticed Paper
description: A document sent by the search giant to Australian regulators argues that the company doesn’t control enough of the digital ad industry to overcharge customers or block competitors.
content: WASHINGTON — Google has largely stayed quiet about its conversations with federal investigators as the Justice Department has looked into whether the company abused its dominance of the online advertising market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: The Case Against Ghislaine Maxwell
description: The socialite linked with Jeffrey Epstein is expected to appear in court Tuesday to face charges of facilitating the abuse of teenage girls.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Louis Colavecchio, Master Counterfeiter of Slot Machine Coins, Dies at 78
description: Mr. Colavecchio, a former jewelry maker whose nickname was “The Coin,” crafted fakes so good that even officials had a hard time telling his coins from legitimate ones under a microscope.
content: In 1996, just after Louis Colavecchio was arrested by Secret Service agents and New Jersey gaming troopers at Caesars Palace in Atlantic City, he laughed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Newsom Announces Rollbacks in California’s Reopening Plans
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he was moving to close indoor operations for restaurants, wineries, movie theaters and zoos. Bars would be forced to close all operations.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he was moving to close indoor operations for restaurants, wineries, movie theaters and zoos. Bars would be forced to close all operations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Some Republicans Say Florida Convention Is ‘a Risk You Have to Take’
description: But the Texas Supreme Court said the state Republican Party could not force a Houston venue to host its convention. A new poll in Texas, meanwhile, showed Joe Biden leading President Trump.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the 2020 Election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Zindzi Mandela, Activist in South Africa and Ambassador, Dies at 59
description: She was ambassador to Denmark after years as a voice against apartheid (sometimes in poetry) alongside her parents, Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Zindziswa Mandela, the youngest daughter of Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, who found her own voice as an activist and poet, died in Johannesburg on Monday. She was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: How Koalas With an S.T.D. Could Help Humanity
description: When it comes to finding a vaccine for chlamydia, the world’s most common sexually transmitted infection, koalas may prove a key ally.
content: TOORBUL, Australia — The first sign is the smell: smoky, like a campfire, with a hint of urine. The second is the koala’s rear end: If it is damp and inflamed, with streaks of brown, you know the animal is in trouble. Jo, lying curled and unconscious on the examination table, had both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Manchester City’s Champions League Ban Is Overturned
description: The club, one of the world’s richest teams, had faced a two-year exile from Europe’s top soccer competition. Its victory is a blow to the credibility of UEFA’s cost control rules.
content: LONDON — Almost as soon as it was accused of breaking European soccer’s cost control rules, Manchester City dug in and began the fight to clear its name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: California and its schools roll back reopenings.
content: Los Angeles and San Diego Counties said schools would be online-only in the fall, citing a surge in infections that pose too much risk for students and teachers. The unified school districts, with around 825,000 students, are the largest so far in the U.S. to abandon plans for even a partial physical return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Newsom Announces Rollbacks in California’s Reopening Plans
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he was moving to close indoor operations for restaurants, wineries, movie theaters and zoos. Bars would be forced to close all operations.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he was moving to close indoor operations for restaurants, wineries, movie theaters and zoos. Bars would be forced to close all operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Hong Kong Restrictions, Seoul Mayor, Christchurch Shooter: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: As jobs move online, retraining workers becomes a priority.
description: Economists, business leaders and labor experts have warned for years that a coming wave of automation and digital technology would upend the work force, destroying some jobs while altering how and where work is done for nearly everyone.
content: Economists, business leaders and labor experts have warned for years that a coming wave of automation and digital technology would upend the work force, destroying some jobs while altering how and where work is done for nearly everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: ESPN Employees Say Racism Endures Behind the Camera
description: In meetings and conversations among colleagues, ESPN employees have criticized the career pipeline and diversity of top leadership, eliciting a promise from executives to do better.
content: The nationwide conversation over systemic racism and equality has prompted a series of discussions and forums at ESPN, where Black employees, many of them behind the cameras, have begun speaking out about the everyday racism and barriers they face at the sports media giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Black
title: With Robot Deliveries and Outdoor Tents, Campus Dining Will Be Very Different
description: It is still unclear how many students will return to college campuses this fall, but for those who do, mealtime will change dramatically.
content: By Becky Vuksta’s calculations, the new socially distanced dining-hall setup at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., will serve 12 students a minute, or 720 students per hour. Not bad, but still not fast enough to feed the school’s 2,700 students in the rush between classes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Some Republicans Say Florida Convention Is ‘a Risk You Have to Take’
description: But the Texas Supreme Court said the state Republican Party could not force a Houston venue to host its convention. A new poll in Texas, meanwhile, showed Joe Biden leading President Trump.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the 2020 Election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Zindzi Mandela, Activist in South Africa and Ambassador, Dies at 59
description: She was ambassador to Denmark after years as a voice against apartheid (sometimes in poetry) alongside her parents, Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Zindziswa Mandela, the youngest daughter of Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, who found her own voice as an activist and poet, died in Johannesburg on Monday. She was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Inside the White House, a Gun Industry Lobbyist Delivers for His Former Patrons
description: The Trump administration lifted a ban on sales of silencers to private overseas buyers that was intended to protect U.S. troops from ambushes. The change was championed by a lawyer for the president who had worked for a firearms trade group.
content: Michael B. Williams spent nearly two years helping to run a trade group focused on expanding sales of firearm silencers by American manufacturers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Why Rich New Yorkers Are Causing Big Problems for the Census
description: If residents who fled the virus for second homes aren’t counted, the city could lose out on crucial federal money — and congressional seats.
content: When city officials took on the herculean task of getting every New York City household to fill out the census, an eat-your-vegetables exercise that provides millions in federal aid to low-income residents, they didn’t expect the Upper East Side to pose much of a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Makiko Inoue and Hikari Hida
title: Coronavirus Outbreak at U.S. Bases in Japan Roils an Uneasy Relationship
description: The Marines reported 94 new cases on Okinawa, an island that had seen just 148 other infections. Local officials say the military is not doing enough.
content: TOKYO — An outbreak of coronavirus cases on United States military bases in Okinawa, Japan, has alarmed the island’s local population, which at times has been at odds with the Americans stationed there and has otherwise been successful in limiting Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: How Koalas With an S.T.D. Could Help Humanity
description: When it comes to finding a vaccine for chlamydia, the world’s most common sexually transmitted infection, koalas may prove a key ally.
content: TOORBUL, Australia — The first sign is the smell: smoky, like a campfire, with a hint of urine. The second is the koala’s rear end: If it is damp and inflamed, with streaks of brown, you know the animal is in trouble. Jo, lying curled and unconscious on the examination table, had both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Manchester City’s Champions League Ban Is Overturned
description: The club, one of the world’s richest teams, had faced a two-year exile from Europe’s top soccer competition. Its victory is a blow to the credibility of UEFA’s cost control rules.
content: LONDON — Almost as soon as it was accused of breaking European soccer’s cost control rules, Manchester City dug in and began the fight to clear its name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: California and its schools roll back reopenings.
content: Los Angeles and San Diego Counties said schools would be online-only in the fall, citing a surge in infections that pose too much risk for students and teachers. The unified school districts, with around 825,000 students, are the largest so far in the U.S. to abandon plans for even a partial physical return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: 17 States Sue to Block Student Visa Rules
description: A legal battle between universities and the Trump administration over foreign students and online learning escalated on Monday, ahead of a critical federal court hearing.
content: A Trump administration effort to force foreign college students to take in-person classes in the fall or lose their visas has prompted a high-stakes legal battle between the White House and some of America’s top universities, with 17 states and the District of Columbia joining the fray on Monday in a lawsuit that calls the policy “senseless and cruel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Dana Goldstein
title: Los Angeles and San Diego Schools to Go Online-Only in the Fall
description: California’s two largest districts made the joint call amid a White House push to get children back into classrooms.
content: SACRAMENTO — California’s two largest public school districts said on Monday that instruction would be online-only in the fall, in the latest sign that school administrators are increasingly unwilling to risk crowding students back into classrooms until the coronavirus is fully under control.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: A Record 5.4 Million Americans Have Lost Health Insurance, Study Finds
description: California’s governor announced a sweeping rollback of the state’s reopening and Los Angeles and San Diego school districts will be online-only in the fall. Dr. Anthony Fauci returned to the White House.
content: The coronavirus pandemic stripped an estimated 5.4 million Americans of their health insurance between February and May, a stretch in which more adults became uninsured because of job losses than have ever lost coverage in a single year, according to a new analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Says Most of China’s Claims in South China Sea Are Illegal
description: The announcement by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo portends more American military operations to push back Chinese maritime activity and sanctions on Chinese companies.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced on Monday that China’s expansive maritime claims across most of the South China Sea were “completely unlawful,” setting up potential military confrontations with Beijing and sanctions against companies as the United States seeks to push back Chinese activity in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The N.Y.P.D. Has Rejected Reform for Decades. It Can’t Anymore.
description: New York is finally giving its Police Department the scrutiny it deserves.
content: In New York, a 1-year-old boy was fatally shot over the weekend, one of the latest victims in a surge of violence that has rattled an already traumatized city. As of Monday, New York City had had 634 shootings this year, up from 394 at the same time last year, according to Police Department data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Marder
title: The Case Against Tickling
description: Laughter doesn’t always signal enjoyment, and “stop” should mean “stop.”
content: When she was a young child, Ashley Austrew’s father would hold her down and tickle her so hard she felt momentarily paralyzed. He thought they were having fun — the tickling made her laugh, after all — but she dreaded it. More than once, she rolled off the couch and hit her head on the coffee table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Bienstock
title: David Lee Roth Is Letting His Art (Mostly) Do the Talking
description: Since the Covid-19 pandemic forced him off the road, the singer has been making comics at his Los Angeles home, and calling it performance therapy.
content: Typically, David Lee Roth spends his days, or at least his nights, “in tactical spandex, moving at 134 beats per minute,” he said. But now the 65-year-old Van Halen singer is just like the rest of us: stuck at home and obsessing about pandemics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Pew,’ a Mysterious Stranger Tests a Small Town’s Tolerance
description: The genderless, racially ambiguous and seemingly mute narrator of Catherine Lacey’s third novel makes the people of a Southern town nervous.
content: Does it matter what anybody looks like? Philip Roth wrote that the body’s surface is “as serious a thing as there is in life.” Susan Sontag, in an early diary entry, commented that physical beauty was “enormously, almost morbidly, important to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Harmen Boerboom
title: Suriname Elects a New President, Ending Bouterse’s Long Rule
description: Desi Bouterse has cast a long shadow over Suriname since its independence. Once a dictator, he returned as a populist, but fell in the face of the pandemic and an economic crisis.
content: Suriname elected a new president on Monday, ending the long rule of Desi Bouterse, who dominated the small South American nation’s politics since its independence through intimidation and charisma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Rivas and Will Gordh
title: I’m an Actor of Color. My Curls Aren’t Wanted.
description: I know if I want to land more roles, I need to look white.
content: I know if I want to land more roles, I need to look white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodie Noel Vinson
title: Whipped by the ‘Long Tail’ of the Coronavirus
description: When the E.R. nurse asked if I’d been short of breath that day, I replied that I’d been short of breath for 65 days.
content: On day 45 of our illness, my husband, Marc, and I woke up and looked at each other. Our symptoms had always been eerily in sync. Now the constriction in our chests was unmistakable. It was back. It was worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Hiroko Masuike
title: California’s Rollback, Washington’s N.F.L. team, Koalas: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Bright Outdoor Lights Tied to Less Sleep, More Anxiety in Teenagers
description: The more intense the lighting in teenagers’ neighborhoods, the poorer their sleep and the greater their risk for depression and anxiety.
content: Artificial outdoor light at night may disrupt adolescents’ sleep and raise the risk for psychiatric disorders, a new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: A Big California Quake Just Got ‘a Little Likelier’
description: A new analysis puts the likelihood of an earthquake slightly higher than earlier forecasts, but researchers said there’s no reason to panic.
content: An analysis of recent changes along earthquake faults in Southern California suggests there is an increased possibility of a major quake on the San Andreas Fault, researchers said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Rare Honey for Your Table
description: This new honey from the Savannah Bee Company is made from the nectar of black sage.
content: Black sage, a spiky shrublike plant native to Southern California and Northern Mexico, flowers only about every three years. So black sage honey is a rare thing for the Savannah Bee Company, which buys it from a beekeeper who only gets three to four yields a decade. The honey is earthy and a bit rustic, with a distinctive spiciness. Drizzle it on grilled peaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Body of Naya Rivera Is Found at California Lake, Sheriff Says
description: Ventura County Sheriff Bill Ayub said search teams recovered Ms. Rivera’s body on Monday, almost a week after she was reported missing.
content: Ventura County Sheriff Bill Ayub said search teams recovered Ms. Rivera’s body on Monday, almost a week after she was reported missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘CMA Best of the Fest’ and ‘Foodie Love’
description: The musical festival retrospective special airs on ABC. And an Isabel Coixet series arrives on HBO platforms.
content: FOODIE LOVE Stream on HBO platforms. In this Spanish-language series by the prolific director and screenwriter Isabel Coixet, a man and a woman, played by Guillermo Pfening and Laia Costa, meet through a dating app and bond over their shared loved of food and distaste for the culture that has sprung up around it. Across eight episodes, all of which are now available, their relationship develops against the backdrop of coffee and cocktails, ramen and sake, ice cream and croissants. But as they move further from the virtual into the realm of embodied love, by way of fine dining and frequent snacking, the stakes become higher, their intimacy becomes more intense and their deepening connection is threatened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Pew,’ a Mysterious Stranger Tests a Small Town’s Tolerance
description: The genderless, racially ambiguous and seemingly mute narrator of Catherine Lacey’s third novel makes the people of a Southern town nervous.
content: Does it matter what anybody looks like? Philip Roth wrote that the body’s surface is “as serious a thing as there is in life.” Susan Sontag, in an early diary entry, commented that physical beauty was “enormously, almost morbidly, important to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Big California Quake Just Got ‘a Little Likelier’

content: An analysis of recent changes along earthquake faults in Southern California suggests there is an increased possibility of a major quake on the San Andreas Fault, researchers said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Body of Naya Rivera Is Found at California Lake, Sheriff Says
description: Ventura County Sheriff Bill Ayub said search teams recovered Ms. Rivera’s body on Monday, almost a week after she was reported missing.
content: Ventura County Sheriff Bill Ayub said search teams recovered Ms. Rivera’s body on Monday, almost a week after she was reported missing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Rare Honey for Your Table
description: This new honey from the Savannah Bee Company is made from the nectar of black sage.
content: Black sage, a spiky shrublike plant native to Southern California and Northern Mexico, flowers only about every three years. So black sage honey is a rare thing for the Savannah Bee Company, which buys it from a beekeeper who only gets three to four yields a decade. The honey is earthy and a bit rustic, with a distinctive spiciness. Drizzle it on grilled peaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Kelly Preston, ‘Jerry Maguire’ Star, Dies at 57
description: Ms. Preston, who was married to John Travolta, was known for her role in “Jerry Maguire” as the hardhearted fiancée of the Tom Cruise character.
content: Kelly Preston, an actress best known for her role as a hardhearted fiancée of the Tom Cruise character in the 1996 film “Jerry Maguire,” died on Sunday in Florida. She was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: The Pandemic Has Accelerated Demands for a More Skilled Work Force
description: Even groups that regularly disagree on labor issues said there should be significant public investment in programs that can upgrade the skills of American workers.
content: Economists, business leaders and labor experts have warned for years that a coming wave of automation and digital technology would upend the work force, destroying some jobs while altering how and where work is done for nearly everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Russell Westbrook Says He Tested Positive for the Coronavirus
description: Westbrook, the Houston Rockets guard, said he was “feeling well” in a post on social media on Monday.
content: Russell Westbrook of the Houston Rockets, the N.B.A.’s most valuable player in the 2016-17 season, said on Monday in a social media post that he had tested positive for the coronavirus. He said he received his test result before the team left for Walt Disney World in Florida, where the N.B.A. is attempting to restart its season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Case for Smarter Coronavirus Testing
description: Current tests have a high rate of false negative or false positive results. Smart testing would “help ensure that the right test is given to the right person at the right time.”
content: As Covid-19 continues to wreak havoc in communities around the country, many people are seeking tests for evidence either of the virus itself or antibodies to it, an indicator of past infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: George Soros’s Foundation Pours $220 Million Into Racial Equality Push
description: Mr. Soros’s group will invest $150 million in grants for Black-led racial justice groups, and another $70 million toward local grants for criminal justice reform and civic engagement opportunities.
content: The Open Society Foundations, the philanthropic group founded by the business magnate George Soros, announced on Monday that it was investing $220 million in efforts to achieve racial equality in America, a huge financial undertaking that will support several Black-led racial justice groups for years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Trump Continues Criticism of Movement to Defund the Police
description: The president is embracing law enforcement, a tactic that won him support in the 2016 campaign, while ignoring calls for reform.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday assailed a broad movement to defund police departments, invoking the kind of pro-police language that won him support with the law enforcement community in 2016 and ignoring the calls for reform that have helped shape this election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: DeVos Abandons a Lifetime of Local Advocacy to Demand Schools Reopen
description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has become the face of the Trump administration’s demands, a stance diametrically opposite to how she has led the department.
content: WASHINGTON — As the nation’s public schools plunged into crisis at the outset of the coronavirus outbreak, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos stuck to the message of decades of conservative education advocacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Monika Pronczuk
title: Knife-Wielding Polish Man Flees Into Woods, Hoping to Keep Pet Puma
description: The man eventually complied with a court order to hand over the big cat, which he has kept as a pet for six years.
content: A man in Poland wielded a knife and fled to the woods, refusing to give up his beloved — but illegal — pet puma when officials from a zoo tried to retrieve the animal on Friday, according to local reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Brexit Border Bureaucracy Looms for Truckers, Pet Owners and Travelers
description: Next year businesses and travelers face mounds of new paperwork (and higher cellphone bills) as Britain builds up frontier controls.
content: LONDON — No more seamless access to medical care. A spike in cellphone bills. And months of preparation if you are bringing the dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Imposes Tit-for-Tat Sanctions on Three American Lawmakers
description: The sanctions, which target Republican members of Congress, were in retaliation for the Trump administration’s bans on Chinese officials accused of human rights abuses.
content: BEIJING — As tensions between the two sides mount, the Chinese government announced on Monday that it would impose sanctions on three American lawmakers and a diplomat in retaliation for similar moves last week by the Trump administration against four  officials in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ‘I Felt Defenseless’: Seoul Mayor’s Secretary Speaks Out About Alleged Abuse.
description: Her lawyer, who issued a statement on the day of Mayor Park Won-soon’s funeral, is calling for an investigation into accusations of sexual harassment.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — The secretary to one of the most powerful political figures in South Korea, Mayor Park Won-soon of Seoul, described suffering years of abuse and sexual harassment at his hands, calling in her first public statement on Monday for a world where women can be treated “like humans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Nicholas Fandos and Patricia Mazzei
title: Headed to the Convention? Not I, More Republicans Are Saying
description: “Everybody just assumes no one is going,” said one House member wary of the virus risks. But other delegates dismissed the health threat and said it was an honor to help nominate President Trump.
content: Senators Roy Blunt of Missouri and Pat Roberts of Kansas are planning to skip the Republican National Convention next month as the host state of Florida deals with the biggest outbreak of coronavirus cases in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: Monthly U.S. Budget Deficit Soared to Record $864 Billion in June
description: The shortfall was nearly as large as the entire 2019 deficit as spending on virus-related efforts outpaced revenues.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States budget deficit grew to a record $864 billion for June as the federal government pumped huge sums of money into the economy to prop up workers and businesses affected by the coronavirus, the Treasury Department said on Monday, an amount that is expected to grow as a surge in cases portends prolonged economic pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Kevin Draper
title: Redskins to Drop Name, Yielding to Pressure From Sponsors and Activists
description: The N.F.L. team in Washington announced the move on Monday and will continue its search for a new name and logo.
content: First, the city of Washington took down a tribute to George Preston Marshall, the founder of its N.F.L. team, that was in front of the team’s old home, Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium. Then the team removed references to Marshall, who named his team the “Redskins,” from inside its stadium and at its training facility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: ‘I Can’t Keep Doing This:’ Small-Business Owners Are Giving Up
description: More owners are permanently shutting their doors after new lockdown orders, realizing that there may be no end in sight to the crisis.
content: On the last Friday of June, after Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said that bars across the state would have to shut down a second time because coronavirus cases were skyrocketing, Mick Larkin decided he had had enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Gross
title: Want to Abolish the Police? Consider Becoming an Officer Instead
description: If more people in law enforcement cared about the things progressives support, we’d all benefit.
content: For the past few years, I’ve taught a seminar on the sociology of the police at Colby College in Maine. My students, mostly progressive, ask me whether there’s anything they can do to help solve some of the serious problems that exist in policing, such as racial inequities in the use of force, the overpolicing of minority neighborhoods and rogue officers who lie to justify arrests. Today, young people all over the country are asking the same question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Supreme Court Lifts Block on Federal Execution
description: A district court in Washington, D.C., had put the execution of Daniel Lewis Lee on hold hours before it was to be carried out. The Supreme Court cleared the way in a late-night, unsigned ruling.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court early on Tuesday cleared the way for the Justice Department to carry out the first federal execution in more than 17 years, removing a federal judge’s hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy, Elaine Yu and Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Voters Defy Beijing, Endorsing Protest Leaders in Primary
description: Voters turned out in high numbers to cast ballots in an unofficial primary for the city’s pro-democracy camp despite government warnings it might be against the new security law.
content: HONG KONG — Defying warnings from local officials that the Hong Kong opposition’s unofficial primary vote could be illegal under a sweeping new security law, hundreds of thousands of people chose avowedly pro-democracy candidates to run in citywide elections this year, results released Monday showed.
source.name: The New York Times
